meanings.def: a document that shows how much you owe somebody for goods or services
examples: the phone/electricity/gas bill
He is facing a huge tax bill.
She always pays her bills on time.
We ran up a massive hotel bill.
bill for something I’ll be sending you the bill for the dry-cleaning!
The bills are piling up (= there are more and more that have still not been paid).
Customers receive an itemized monthly phone bill.
Don't worry—the company will pick up the bill (= pay).
I've just got a huge tax bill.
Many people struggle to pay their rent and utility bills.
The company could now face higher fuel bills.
They presented us with a very large bill.
Use the money in the account to cover the bills.

meanings.def: a piece of paper that shows how much you have to pay for the food and drinks that you have had in a restaurant
examples: Let's ask for the bill.
Could we have the bill, please?
the gas bill
Put it on my account please.
The builders sent an invoice for £250.
Can I have the check, please?
Are the coffees on the bill?
Could I have the bill please?
The bill came to £120.
We decided to split the bill (= share the cost of the meal).
The waiter brought the bill to their table.
a ten-dollar bill

meanings.def: a written suggestion for a new law that is presented to a country’s parliament so that its members can discuss it
examples: to introduce/approve/oppose a bill
Congress passed the energy bill last month.
Republicans said they would support the bill.
the Education Reform Bill
The bill will be brought before Parliament next year.
Republicans will try to push the bill through Congress.
The bill was brought to the floor of the House last summer.
The bill became law in June.
The government has put forward an emergency bill to limit the powers of the police.

meanings.def: a programme of entertainment at a theatre, etc.
examples: a horror double bill (= two horror films shown one after the other)
Topping the bill (= the most important performer) is violinist Joshua Bell.
Mozart is on the bill this evening.

meanings.def: a notice in a public place to advertise an event
examples: Post no bills (= a notice warning people not to stick bills in a particular place).

meanings.def: the hard pointed or curved outer part of a bird’s mouth
having the type of bill mentioned
examples: long-billed waders

meanings.def: the stiff front part of a cap that sticks out above your eyes
a report that says somebody is healthy or that something is in good condition
examples: Doctors gave him a clean bill of health after a series of tests and examinations.
The building was given a clean bill of health by the surveyor.

meanings.def: to be what is needed in a particular situation or for a particular purpose
examples: On paper, several of the applicants fit the bill.

meanings.def: to be responsible for paying the cost of something
examples: Once again it will be the taxpayer who has to foot the bill.
Who will be footing the bill for the party?

idioms.def: a report that says somebody is healthy or that something is in good condition
examples: Doctors gave him a clean bill of health after a series of tests and examinations.
The building was given a clean bill of health by the surveyor.

idioms.def: to be what is needed in a particular situation or for a particular purpose
examples: On paper, several of the applicants fit the bill.

idioms.def: to be responsible for paying the cost of something
examples: Once again it will be the taxpayer who has to foot the bill.
Who will be footing the bill for the party?

meanings.def: to send somebody a bill for something
examples: bill somebody for something Please bill me for the books.
You will be billed monthly for the service.
bill somebody We are changing the way that we bill our customers.
bill somebody something He only billed me £130.
bill something to somebody/something The cost will be billed to your account.

meanings.def: to advertise or describe somebody/something in a particular way
examples: be billed as something He was billed as the new Tom Cruise.

meanings.def: to advertise that somebody/something will do something
examples: be billed to do something She was billed to speak on ‘China—Yesterday and Today’.

meanings.def: if two people who are in love bill and coo, they kiss and speak in a loving way to each other

idioms.def: if two people who are in love bill and coo, they kiss and speak in a loving way to each other

meanings.def: a first name for boys, short for William

(1925-81) the US singer who, with his group the Comets, first made rock and roll popular. They recorded Shake, Rattle and Roll and then Rock Around the Clock, which Haley wrote. It was used in the film The Blackboard Jungle (1955) and became an international hit, with 22.5 million copies sold.

(1893-1953) a US tennis player who was the leading player in the world during the 1920s. His popular name was 'Big Bill'. In 1920 he became the first American to win at Wimbledon, and he also won there in 1921 and 1930. He won the US Open seven times (1920-25 and 1929) and played in 11 Davis Cup teams.
